revision.comment: Parsecboy moved page [[SAS Isandlwana (F146)]] to [[SAS Isandlwana]]: no other ships with this name, no need for dab
revision.text:

flag= {{shipboxflag|South Africa|naval}} |Ship name= SAS ''Isandlwana'' |Ship namesake= [[Battle of Isandlwana]] |Ship ordered=3 December 1999 |Ship builder= [[Howaldtswerke-Deutsche Werft]], [[Kiel]] |Ship operator=[[South African Navy]] |Ship laid down= 28 October 2001 |Ship launched= 5 December 2002 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned= 20 July 2006 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service= |Ship struck= |Ship reinstated= |Ship homeport=Simonstown |Ship motto= |Ship nickname= |Ship honours= |Ship status={{Ship in active service}} |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox ship characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= {{sclass2|Valour|frigate}} |Ship displacement= {{convert|3700|LT|t|0|lk=in|abbr=on}} |Ship length={{convert|121|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship beam= {{convert|16.34|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship draught= {{convert|5.95|m|ftin|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=*[[Combined diesel and gas#CODAG WARP|CODAG WARP]] *2 × Diesels {{convert|5920|kW|hp|0|abbr=on}} each *2 shafts *1 × Gas turbine {{convert|20000|kW|hp|0|abbr=on}} *1 Waterjet |Ship speed= {{convert|30|kn|lk=in}} |Ship range= {{convert|8000|nmi|km|lk=in|abbr=on}} at {{convert|16|kn}} |Ship complement=152 |Ship sensors=* '''Surveillance Radar''': Thales Naval France MRR-3D NG G-band multi-role radar * '''Optical Radar Tracker''': 2 Reutech RTS 6400 monopulse X-band (I/J bands) combined radar and optronics trackers * '''Electro-optical Tracker''': Reutech Electro-optical tracker * '''Identification Friend or Foe''': Tellumat Integrated Naval IFF system * '''Target Designation Sights''': M-Tek Target Designation Sights * '''Sonar''': Thales UMS4132 Kingklip sonar * '''Obstacle avoidance sonar''': MDS 3060 |Ship EW=* '''ESM/ECM''': Saab Grintek Avitronics SME 100/200 ESM (Intercept and Jammer) & ELINT * '''Decoys''': 2 Saab Grintek Avitronics MRL Super Barricade chaff launchers (96 decoys) |Ship armament=*1 × [[Otobreda 76 mm]] gun *1 × twin barreled 35 mm [[Denel 35mm Dual Purpose Gun|(Denel) dual purpose gun]] *2 × [[Oerlikon 20 mm cannon]] Mk1 *8 × [[MBDA]] MM40 [[Exocet]] Block 2 [[Surface-to-surface missile|SSM]] (2 × 4-cell launchers) *16 × [[Umkhonto (missile)|Umkhonto]] [[Surface-to-air missile|SAM]] (2 × 8-cell vertical launchers)
|Ship aircraft=1 × [[Westland Lynx|SuperLynx 300]] (can carry 2) |Ship aircraft facilities=* Flight deck * Enclosed [[hangar]] |Ship notes= }} |} '''SAS ''Isandlwana'' (F146)''' is the second of four [[Valour class frigate|Valour class]] [[frigate]]s for the [[South African Navy]] built by the European South African Corvette Consortium. SAS Isandlwana was named after the [[Battle of Isandlwana]] at a ceremony held in Kiel in December 2002, by Deputy Defence Minister [[Nozizwe Madlala-Routledge]].<ref>[http://www.allatsea.co.za/sanavyships.htm South African Navy Ships<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==Construction== SAS Isandlwana was manufactured by the European South African Corvette Consortium (ESACC), consisting of the German Frigate Consortium (Blohm+Voss, Thyssen Rheinstahl and [[Howaldtswerke]] Deutsche Werft), African Defence Systems (part of the French [[Thales Group|Thales]] defense group) and a number of South African companies.<ref>[http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/meko/ MEKO A Class Combat Ship Family - Naval Technology<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
The ships were built to the [[MEKO]] modular design concept, and are designated by the manufacturer as the '''MEKO A-200SAN''' class. Some controversy exists as to the class type of the vessel, with both the manufacturer and the South African Navy referring to her as a "[[corvette]]", but other similar vessels in other navies being referred to as frigates. Some have claimed the use of the word "corvette" was a political decision made by the South African government to ease criticism of the procurement of the vessels.
The SAS ''Isandlwana'' was built at the [[Howaldtswerke]]-Deutsche Werft shipyards in [[Kiel]], [[Germany]], and she arrived in [[South Africa]] on 25 February 2004.<ref>[http://www.navy.mil.za/equipment/valour.htm Valour-class Frigates<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In 2007, the SAS ''Isandlwana'' took part in the Atlasur Exercise in cooperation with the fleets of [[Brazil]] and [[Chile]].<ref>{{cite news|publisher=News24|url=http://www.news24.com/Regional_Papers/Components/Category_Article_Text_Template/0,2430,433-441-444_2076963~E,00.html|title=First black commander for frigate|date=2007-03-01|accessdate=2009-02-08}}</ref>
==Namesake== As with all the other ships of the Valour class, the ''Isandlwana'' is named after a famous South African battle or instance of great valour. In this case the famous [[Battle of Isandlwana]] between the [[Zulu Kingdom|Zulu nation]] and the [[British Empire]], at the beginning of the [[Anglo-Zulu War]].
==Notable Deployments== *Exercise Atlasur VI<ref>[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200610/12/eng20061012_311064.html People's Daily Online - South African navy joins exercise with South American nations<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Expo Naval in [[Chile]]<ref>[http://ports.co.za/navalnews/article_2007_03_12_1952.html SAS Isandlwana on her way home from South America<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Exercise Amazolo<ref>[http://ports.co.za/news/article_2007_08_29_5828.html Ports & Ships Maritime News<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Exercise Red Lion<ref>[http://ports.co.za/navalnews/article_2008_02_16_4913.html Navy uses ex German minesweeper for target practice<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Exercise Good Hope III<ref>[http://ports.co.za/navalnews/article_2008_02_19_5429.html German ships here for joint exercise Operation Good Hope III<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Exercise Ibsamar I<ref>[http://www.mar.mil.br/menu_v/operacoes_navais/OperacaoIBISAMAR.htm Operação IBSAMAR I<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> *Exercise Atlasur VII<ref>[http://marinebiztv.wordpress.com/2008/07/30/ 30 « July « 2008 « Marine BizTV<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
